facts.text: Appeals numbered Cases Nos. 283 to 295 of 1951 were filed under article 132(1) of the Constitution of India.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION. Cases Nos. 283 to 295 of 1951. Appeals under article 132  1  of the Constitution of India from the judgment

facts.text: Appeals arose from judgment and decree dated 10th May 1951 of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad by Malik C.J. and others in various writ applications.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and decree dated 10th May, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad  Malik C.J., Mootham, Chandiramani, Agarwala and Bhargava J.J.  in Writ Applications Nos. 23, 25, 3330, 3329, 3331 and 3332 of 1951 and Misc

facts.text: One appeal from judgment and order dated 9th July 1951 of Sapru and Agarwala JJ in Writ Application No. 3403 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: ellaneous Judicial Cases Nos. 1 and 2 of 1951 and Civil Miscellaneous Nos. 335, 340, 345 of 1951  Lucknow Bench  and from the judgment and order dated 9th July, 1951, of Sapru and Agarwala J.J in Writ Application No. 3403 of 1951. 1058 The facts that gave rise to these appeals and petitions are stated in the judgment.

facts.text: Appellants in most cases are owners and proprietors of extensive landed properties in Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants in most of them are owners and proprie- tors of extensive landed properties in the State of Uttar Pradesh. Some of them are holders of estates in Oudh under taluqdari sanads granted to their ancestors by the British Government.

facts.text: H.H. Maharaja Paramjit Singh of Kapurthala, appellant in Appeal No. 285 of 1951, holds an estate in Oudh guaranteed under article XII of the Pepsu Covenant of Merger.

anchor.surface_text: H.H. Maharaja Paramjit Singh of Kapurthala, appellant in Appeal No. 285 of 1951, is the holder of an estate in Oudh, the full ownership, use and enjoyment of which was guaranteed to him by the Government of India under article XII of the Pepsu Covenant of Merger.

facts.text: Appeals Nos. 291 to 295 of 1951 preferred by religious institutions holding endowed properties.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals Nos. 291 to 295 of 1951 have been preferred by religious institu- tions holding endowed properties.

facts.text: On 8th August 1946, United Provinces Legislative Assembly passed resolution accepting principle of abolition of zamindari system on payment of equitable compensation.

anchor.surface_text: On 8th August, 1946, the United Provinces. Legislative Assembly passed the following resolution -- 1059 This Assembly accepts the principle of the abolition of the zamindari system in this Province which involves inter- mediaries between the cultivator and the State and resolves that the rights of such intermediaries should be acquired on payment of equitable compensation

facts.text: Committee appointed to prepare scheme for zamindari abolition made report in July 1948.

anchor.surface_text: and that Government should appoint a committee t0 prepare a scheme for this purpose. A committee was appointed to give effect to the resolu- tion and to prepare the necessary scheme. It made its report in July, 1948.

facts.text: Bill introduced in United Provinces Legislative Assembly on 7th July 1949.

anchor.surface_text: A Bill was introduced in the United Provinces Legislative Assembly on the 7th July, 1949, was referred to a Select Committee which made its report on 9th January, 1950, and was read before the Assembly for the first time on 17th January, 1950.

facts.text: Bill passed by Legislative Assembly on 10th January 1951, by Legislative Council, received President's assent, came into force on or about 25th January 1951.

anchor.surface_text: the Bill was reintroduced in the Legislative Assembly on 26th December, 1950, and was passed in its amended form on 10th January, 1951. It was subse- quently passed by the Legislative Council and after having received the assent of the President came into force on or about the 25th January, 1951.

facts.text: Uttar Pradesh Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, U.P. Act I of 1951, provides for abolition of zamindari system and acquisition of intermediaries' rights.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals under article 132 1  of the Constitution concern the constitutionality of an Act known as the Uttar Pradesh Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act  U. P. Act I of 1951 , and can be conveniently disposed of by one judgment.

facts.text: Under section 4(1), all estates in Uttar Pradesh vest in State free from encumbrances by notification.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  1  of section 4 provides that as from such date as the State Government may by notification declare, all estates situated in the Uttar Pradesh shall vest in the State free from all encumbrances.

facts.text: Section 6: Rights, title and interest of intermediaries in estates vest in State free from encumbrances upon notification under section 4.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 enacts that subject to certain very minor exceptions, upon the publication of a notification under section 4, the rights, title and interest of all intermediaries in every estate in the area referred to in the notification, and in all sub-soil in such estates including rights if any, in mines and minerals, shall cease and shall be vested in the State of Uttar Pradesh free from all encumbrances.

facts.text: Intermediaries entitled to compensation at eight times the net assets in Compensation Assessment Roll.

anchor.surface_text: The intermediaries whose rights, title and interest are thus acquired become entitled to receive compensation at eight times the net assets mentioned in the Compensation Assessment Roll prepared in accordance with the provisions of the Act.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court dismissed writ petitions on 10th May 1951.

anchor.surface_text: By a judgment of a Full Bench of the Allahabad High Court delivered on 10th May, 1951, the petitions were dismissed.

facts.text: High Court certified under article 132(1) substantial questions of law as to interpretation of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, certified, under article 132 1 , that the cases involved substantial questions of law as to the interpreta- tion of the Constitution.

facts.text: Bill was pending in legislature on 26th January 1950 when Constitution came into force.

anchor.surface_text: This Bill was pending in the legislature of the. State on the 26th January, 1950, when the Constitu- tion came into force and this circumstance makes article 31  4  applicable to all these cases.

facts.text: Compensation due as from date of vesting with interest at 2.5% per annum.

anchor.surface_text: 28.  1 . Compensation for acquisition of estates under this Act shall be due as from the date of vesting subject to determination of the amount thereof. There shall be paid by the State Government on the amount so determined interest at the rate of two and half per centum per annum from the date of vesting

facts.text: Pepsu Covenant of Merger dated 5th May 1948 guaranteed Maharaja's Oudh estate under article 12.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the appeal of the Maharaja of Kapurthala  Appeal No. 285 of 1951 , the facts are these By article 12 of the Covenant of Merger dated the 5th 1077 May, 1948, entered into between the Rulers of the States comprising in the Pepsu Union, the properties which are the subject-matter of the appeal were declared and guaranteed as the private properties of the Maharaja.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed all appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The result therefore is that there is no substance in any one of the appeals and I would accordingly dismiss all of them.
Appeals under article 132  1  of the Constitution of India from the judgment and decree dated 10th May, 1951, of the High Court

holdings.text: The impugned Act was validly enacted as the Bill was pending in the legislature on 26th January 1950 making Article 31(4) applicable.

anchor.surface_text: This Bill was pending in the legislature of the. State on the 26th January, 1950, when the Constitu- tion came into force and this circumstance makes article 31  4  applicable to all these cases. It was

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bill pending at Constitution commencement per Art 196; does not lapse on prorogation; Art 31(4) shields from Art 31(2) challenge.

holdings.text: Provisions of Articles 31A and 31B completely shelter the Act from attack under Part III.

anchor.surface_text: Further the provisions of articles 31-A and 31-B completely shelter this law from any attack based on any of the provisions of Part III of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: President's assent validates against fundamental rights challenges.

holdings.text: Acquisition under the Act is for a public purpose.

holdings.text: I hold that the impugned Act is not void by reason of the circumstance that it does not postulate a public purpose.

anchor.surface_text: the matter seems to have been set at rest by the decision of their Lordships of the Privy Council in Thakur Jagannath Baksh Singh v. United Provinces 1 . At page 119 of the report it was observed as follows- It is,however,desirable to examine the particular grounds on which it is sought to induce the companyrt to arrive at this paradoxical companyclusion. Some of these are said to be based on the general principle of law that the Crown cannot dero- gate from its own grant, others are said to depend on par- ticular provisions of the Government of India Act.

precedents.case_name: Thakur Jagannath Baksh Singh v. United Provinces
precedents.cited_proposition: Parliament, whether Imperial, Federal or Provincial, in the absence of express prohibition, is not debarred from legislating so as to vary the effect of a Crown grant; the Crown cannot deprive a legislature of its legislative authority by making a grant of land
precedents.cited_holding: no court can annul the enactment of a legislative body acting within the legitimate scope of its sovereign competence
